entry.title: Process modelling in SAP Signavio by importing process data that is mined in Celonis
entry.content:
Hi,

Has anyone tried to do Process Modeling in Signavio by importing SAP Process Data that is mined in Celonis? Basically, what i am interested in knowing is if it is possible to generate process maps automatically in Signavio by importing process data/BPMN from Celonis. Intent here is to avoid creating process models manually in SAP Signavio. I'd be really interested in knowing if this could be done and if so, what's the recommended approach?

I know this ask may sound strange, but the organization's strategy is to use Celonis for process data mining and Signavio for Process Modeling.

Thanks,

Gokul

Overview

Learning objectives

Kind regards
Susann

entry.title: SAP Business Network for Logistics 2507 – What’s New?
entry.content:
We’re thrilled to announce that the latest SAP Business Network for Logistics release, 2507, went live this past weekend! This release introduces exciting enhancements across SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration and Global Track and Trace.

This month’s updates include noteworthy new features, particularly regarding dock appointment scheduling. Additionally, our development team has published a blog post detailing the newly introduced concept of ‘derived appointment duration.’

Let’s dive into the key features and updates!

 

Across SAP Business Network for Logistics

Automated EDI Pulling

You can now use a scheduler to automate EDI pulling operations for ANSI and EDIFACT inbound messages. This feature allows you to configure the pulling frequency when setting up the EDI Inbound All service. For example, pulling jobs can be scheduled to run at specific times each day or on selected days of the week.

For more information on EDI pulling, click here.

 

SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration

New Codes Available for ‘Note Types’

The ‘Note Types’ codes have been enhanced with the following new values:

  • TERMP: Full container drop-off location at pre-carriage
  • TERMO: Full container pickup location at on-carriage
  • TERME: Empty container return terminal
  • TERML: Empty container pick-up terminal
  • BOLTY: Original Bill of Lading vs. Seaway (Copy) Bill of Lading
  • BLCNO: Quantity of Bill of Lading Copies / Seaway
  • BLONO: Quantity of Original Bill of Lading
  • BOLTX: Free text to be printed on the Bill of Lading

Contracting: ‘Freight Orders for Confirmation’ App – View Custom Charge Codes

Carriers can now view custom charge codes alongside their descriptions—maintained by shippers—on the ‘Charges’ tab within the ‘Freight Orders for Confirmation’ app. This enhancement enables carriers to better understand freight orders prior to confirmation.

 

Dock Appointment Scheduling: Derived Appointment Duration

The derived appointment duration feature allows shippers to optimize dock utilization by calculating the expected loading and unloading durations.

Derived appointment duration is derived from the scheduling settings in SAP Transportation Management (SAP TM) or from transportation management (TM) in SAP S/4HANA based on various factors—such as cargo start and end dates, weight, volume, or the requested start and end dates. Alternatively, shippers can use the requested start and end dates from the ’Provider API for Dock Appointment Scheduling’.

Shippers must enable this functionality per loading point using the ‘Manage Entities’ app.

Once activated, carriers can view the derived appointment duration under the ‘Scheduling’ tab in the ‘Self-Book Dock Appointments’ app.

 Key Considerations:

  • The booked time slots must align with the calculated duration provided by the shipper.
  • If an exact match is unavailable, the booked time must not exceed the calculated duration by more than one time slot.
  • While carriers are restricted by this rule, shippers retain the ability to overbook (e.g., book additional time slots if needed).

This feature was introduced in response to customer feedback. For a detailed explanation, check out the development team’s blog post covering this topic. 

 

Dock Appointment Scheduling: Improved In-App Help for the ‘Manage Entities’ App

In the loading point section of the ‘Manage Entities’ app, in-app help is now enabled for selected fields, such as ‘Time Slot Booking’ or ‘Capacity and Time Slot At.’ This enhancement simplifies the process of configuring loading point settings.

 

Dock Appointment Scheduling: New Filters in the ‘Manage Dock Appointments’ App

Shippers maintaining appointments in the calendar view can now apply the following filters in the ‘Select Order for Appointment’ dialogue:

  • Arrival Date and Time
  • Departure Date and Time

 

Settlement: Dispute Management for Missing Attachments

The ‘Manage Disputes’ app now supports dispute cases arising from missing attachments. Shippers can reject disputes with the reason code 015: Missing Attachment.

Carriers, in turn, can add the required notes or attachments and resubmit the dispute without needing to adjust the charged amount.

 

SAP Business Network Global Track and Trace

Enhanced ‘Source’ Filter in the ‘Manage Message Logs’ App

To improve search usability, the Source ID filter and column have been renamed to Source. Now, you can search for messages by the business partner connected to you, in addition to their source system ID.

If a message originates from a connected business partner, their name will be displayed in the corresponding column for greater clarity. Clicking the name reveals detailed information in a pop-up view.

 

Track Shipments: Impact Analysis Now Available for All Shipments

In the ‘Track Shipments’ app, the impact analysis feature—accessible on the shipment details page—is now available for all shipments, not just those experiencing delays or running late..

By clicking the analysis option in the top-right corner, solution users can view upstream documents affected by the shipment. Note that impact analysis is no longer accessible via the tracking timeline. 

 

We hope you find the 2507 release updates valuable in optimizing your logistics and supply chain operations! If you have feedback or questions, let us know in the comments below—we’d love to hear your thoughts.

---------------------

A full overview of the 2507 release can be found under the following link.

To learn more about SAP Business Network for Logistics visit SAP - Business Network for Logistics.

For further questions and feedback related to the blog, please check the Q&A area and feel free to post your questions in the link with the tag SAP Business Network for Logistics.

entry.title: Does SAP Public Cloud WM work with Zebra MC3401 with android 13/14?
entry.content:
Hi,

I want to upgrade my scanners to the MC3401 with android 13/14. SAP only has one reference device mc9300 with android 11. To me it seems weird that it should only work on devices with android 11. My question is can I upgrade to MC3401 with android 13/14 with no problems?
EDIT: After some more digging my conclusion is that public runs on SAPGUI5 and this supports the newer android versions:
https://help.sap.com/docs/ABAP_PLATFORM_NEW/468a97775123488ab3345a0c48cadd8f/74b59efa0eef48988d3b716bd0ecc933.html?version=202210.000&locale=en-US
Because scanners use webview the scanners fall in the category of phones&tablets. 
Conclusion is that the scanner with android 13/14 will work fine with public cloud. Correct me if im wrong

entry.title: Führungskräfte als Treiber des Wandels: Insights aus der Kaffee Ecke mit Melanie Zucker von adidas
entry.content:
In der letzten Kaffee Ecke vor der Sommerpause widmeten wir uns der Frage wie Führungskräfte Lern- und Veränderungsprozesse in SAP-Projekten erfolgreich gestalten können. Melanie Zucker von adidas brachte ihre langjährige Erfahrung aus internationalen SAP-Transformationsprojekten ein und gab praxisnahe Einblicke in die Herausforderungen und Erfolgsfaktoren für Führungskräfte im Change Management.

Zum Check-In fragten wir nach den aktuellen Rollen – der Teilnehmenden der Kaffee-Ecke: Führungskräfte, Change Manager:innen, Berater:innen, IT-Leads und HR-Expert:innen, was für eine breite Perspektive sorgte.

Zur Einstimmung fragte Melanie, was Führung für die Teilnehmenden bedeutet: Die Antworten reichten von „Vertrauen“, „Orientierung“, „Empowerment“ bis zu „gemeinsame Ziele erreichen“ und „Rücken freihalten“.

Melanie strukturierte ihren Impuls entlang der drei klassischen Change-Phasen Prepare, Manage und Sustain und ging zu Beginn auf das Big Picture der Change Journey einer Führungskraft ein:

 

Phase 1 - Prepare: Das Fundament für erfolgreichen Wandel

In der Vorbereitungsphase steht die Bewusstseinsbildung im Mittelpunkt. Führungskräfte müssen sich zunächst ihrer eigenen Haltung zum Change bewusst werden und das "Warum" der Veränderung klar definieren. Melanie beschrieb das Beispiel von einem S/4-Projekt Change Impact Workshops mit Führungskräften, um auf strategischer Ebene die Veränderungen in Prozessen und Daten zu verstehen. Daraus entstand ein gemeinsames Zielbild, das später mit den Teams zu konkreten "Month in the Life of..."-Szenarien weiterentwickelt wurde.

Ein besonders wirkungsvolles Tool in dieser Phase erwies sich das Team Canvas: Darin werden Rollen, Verantwortlichkeiten und der gemeinsame Purpose partizipativ erarbeitet, um von Beginn an Orientierung und Einbindung zu schaffen. Das Konzept der psychologischen Sicherheit nach Amy Edmondson bildete dabei die Grundlage für eine offene Feedbackkultur und erhöhte Lernbereitschaft.

In den folgenden Illustrierungen der jeweiligen Phase sind die Leitfragen und Aufgaben für Führungskräfte jeweils in einer Box, die Aufgaben für Change & Learning Leads in einem Pfeil illustriert.

Phase 2 - Manage: Skills und Mindset entwickeln

Die Umsetzungsphase fokussiert auf die gezielte Kompetenzentwicklung von Führungskraft und Team. Melanie setzte beispielsweise Skill-Matrizen ein, um Kompetenzen in den Bereichen Prozess, Daten und Soft Skills sichtbar zu machen und systematisch zu entwickeln. In einem SAP-Projekt wurden Mitarbeitende nach Skills und Erfahrungslevel erfasst, um individuelle Entwicklungspläne und Backup-Strategien zu erstellen.

Besonders kreativ war der Einsatz eines Data Mapping Puzzles als spielerisches Element: Teammitglieder mussten Datenobjekte aus verschiedenen Systemen zusammenbringen, was den Dialog förderte und gleichzeitig cross-funktionales Verständnis aufbaute. In Phasen großer Unsicherheit kamen Change-Management-Spiele zum Einsatz, bei denen Storytelling und spielerische Elemente halfen, Ängste abzubauen.

Das Blended Learning-Konzept umfasste Instructor-led Sessions, Self-Learning-Materialien, praktische Learning Labs mit Key Usern, Spotlight Sessions mit Führungskräften und offene Q&A-Foren. Die Learning Hours entwickelten sich dabei von expertengeführten Sessions hin zu interaktiven Formaten, in denen Teilnehmende eigene Fälle einbrachten und gemeinsam Lösungen erarbeiteten.

 

Phase 3 -  Sustain: Nachhaltigkeit durch Rituale und Communities

Die nachhaltige Verankerung erfolgt durch bewusst etablierte Rituale. Die Learning Hours wurden nach Projektende von der Fachabteilung übernommen und in reguläre Quartal -Calls integriert. Eine User Community fungierte als One-Stop-Shop für Self-Learning-Materialien, Q&A und offizielle Kommunikation.

Besonders wichtig erwies sich das bewusste Feiern von Erfolgen – von Go-Live-Partys mit Vorstand und Teamvideos bis hin zu gemeinsamen Aktivitäten nach erfolgreichen Meilensteinen. Diese Rituale verstärken das Gefühl des gemeinsam Erreichten und motivieren für kommende Herausforderungen.

 

Diskussion und Austausch mit den Teilnehmenden / Themen

Zusammenspiel Change Agent - Führungskraft

Die Zusammenarbeit zwischen Führungskraft und Change Agent wurde intensiv diskutiert. In globalen Projekten agieren Change Agents als Multiplikatoren in Lokationen oder Fachbereichen mit regelmäßiger zentraler Abstimmung, während Führungskräfte in gezielten Einzelgesprächen individuell abgeholt werden.

Einsatz von KI-Tools im Change Management

Zum Einsatz von KI-Tools im Change Management sieht Melanie durchaus Potenzial, etwa bei Coaching Apps oder Meetingauswertungen. Aktuell arbeitet sie jedoch hauptsächlich mit bewährten Tools wie PowerPoint, SharePoint und Forms, da viele KI-Anwendungen noch in der Entwicklung sind.

Die Rolle von Peer Learning

Melanie betonte, dass Peer Learning im S/4HANA-Projektteam gezielt eingesetzt wurde, um Wissen, Erfahrungen und Best Practices teamübergreifend zu teilen und beschrieb, dass dies durch regelmäßige, niederschwellige Austauschformate wie Lernzirkel oder kurze wöchentliche Sessions erfolgte, in denen Teams aktuelle Arbeitsergebnisse präsentierten.

Peer Learning fördert laut Melanie nicht nur die fachliche Entwicklung, sondern auch die Motivation und den Zusammenhalt im Team. Sie empfahl, Peer-Learning-Formate wie Lernzirkel auch bereichsübergreifend und mit externen Partnern einzusetzen, um den Wissenstransfer zu stärken.

Change Müdigkeit

Das Thema Change-müdigkeit und Überlastung beschäftigt viele Organisationen. Melanie betonte die Bedeutung von Einzelgesprächen zur individuellen Betreuung und die Nutzung von Feedback als Steuerungsinstrument. In kritischen Phasen, beispielsweise bei mehrfach verschobenem Go-Live wegen Datenproblemen, war die Top-Down-Priorisierung durch den CFO entscheidend für Ressourcensicherung und Fokussierung.

Fazit: Führung als Katalysator für nachhaltigen Wandel

Die Kaffee Ecke verdeutlichte, dass erfolgreiche SAP-Transformationen weit über technische Implementierung hinausgehen. Führungskräfte fungieren als entscheidende Katalysatoren, die durch strukturierte Herangehensweise, gezielte Kompetenzentwicklung und nachhaltige Verankerung den Wandel zum Erfolg führen.

Passend dazu und zum oben erwähnten Peer-Learning eine Einladung zur Learning Circle Experience zu Organizational Change Management in SAP Projekten. Sie findet ab September statt und besteht als dem Lernen in Peer-Groups sowie zentralen Impulsen & Reviews. Hier könnt ihr euch anmelden oder den Link an interessierte Kollegen weiterleiten https://events.sap.com/eur-learning-circle-experienge-organizational-change-management/de_de/home.html

Die nächste Kaffee Ecke findet im September statt. Aktuelle Termine und Anmeldung unter https://go4.events.sap.com/eur-change-training-kaffee-ecke/de_de/home.html

entry.title: Do you want to learn advanced configuration of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, EHS Environment?
entry.content:
I recommend to access our Performing Advanced Configuration and Role Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, EHS Environment Management learning journey.

Overview
This course is designed for technical users working with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, EHS Environment Management. The course provides in-depth guidance on system setup, customization, and role-based access configuration. Learn how to analyze and adjust standard roles and authorization objects, configure essential system components, and ensure smooth technical integration across the SAP landscape.

Learning objectives
This course will prepare you to:

  • Perform the initial setup and activate scope items in SAP Central Business Configuration.
  • Navigate through the configuration environment.
  • Access and configure foundational technical objects.
  • Configure customizing activities.
  • Describe the authorization concept.
  • Perform user maintenance.
  • Perform business role maintenance.
  • Create an authorization trace.
  • Manage business roles.

Prerequisites

  • Discovering SAP EHS Management, environment management is a prerequisite.
  • Managing User Identity and Access in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition can be beneficial for authorization concept.

Please post you question related to the digital learning Journey in the Q&A area. 
Our SAP Learning Experts will get back to you as soon as possible! We are here to support you. 

I appreciate your feedback and we will make sure to continue sharing interesting topics.
 
Kind regards
Margit

entry.title: Supplier Visibility Control in Shared SAP Ariba SLP Environment
entry.content:
Hi All,
Hope you're doing well!

I have a query regarding supplier visibility in SAP Ariba SLP, and I’d be grateful for guidance from the community experts.

Scenario:
Two large companies have formed a collaboration and are operating under a shared SAP Ariba SLP setup. We would like to understand if it’s possible to:

  • Restrict each company’s users to view only their respective suppliers, and

  • Allow visibility to a limited set of common suppliers for both companies.

Is such a configuration supported within Ariba SLP? If so, what are the recommended approaches—such as realm design, permission controls, or custom attributes?

Appreciate your inputs, suggestions, or any relevant best practices.

Best regards,
Sai

entry.title: "Camel execution failed” Error on Fiori Registration (Only in Production) / Impact of Variable Table
entry.content:
Title:

“Camel execution failed” Error on Fiori Registration (Only in Production) / Impact of Variable Table Reference?

Question:

■ Overview

In our Fiori application, an error occurs when clicking the Register button on a transactional entry screen.
The same code works fine in the test environment, but fails in the production environment.

■ Environment Setup (Simplified)

  • CDS view is used to read cost department master data (name anonymized)
  • Backend is Node.js, accessing CDS via CAP service
  • The CDS view references a table, passed via variable in the service

■ Environment Differences

The referenced table has a higher record count in production (e.g. test: 3,000 records, production: 3,500 records).
CDS view definitions and service logic are identical across environments.

■ Error Message (Excerpt)

 
[SqlError: internal error: Camel execution failed. Reason: Cannot process result] { code: 403, sqlState: 'HY000' }

We noticed the generated SQL contains something like JSON_TABLE('{}'), which may be contributing to the failure when handling empty JSON input under certain conditions.

■ Code Example (with variable table name)

Here is the original code using a variable for the table name:

 

 
const result = await this.tx.run(
    SELECT.one.from(table).where(conditions)
);

This code causes a 403 error only in the production environment.

■ Temporary Fix (working version)

When we explicitly provided the table name as a string, the issue was resolved:

const table = 'Z_ACTUAL_COST_DEPT_MASTER'; // ← anonymized actual table name const result = await this.tx.run( SELECT.one.from(table).where(conditions) );

■ Questions

  1. What could be the root cause of the Camel execution failed. Reason: Cannot process result error in this context?
  2. Could the use of JSON_TABLE('{}') in the CDS-generated SQL cause issues in production due to volume or empty JSON input?
  3. Is it possible that using SELECT.from(variable) in CDS behaves differently across environments (e.g. due to view resolution)?
  4. Are there any best practices for safely referencing tables via variables in CDS views, especially for production stability?

■ Notes

  • Table names and record counts are anonymized.

  • I can provide HANA version and CDS definitions if needed.

entry.title: Re: In S/4HANA what transaction will replace VC/2
entry.content:
In S/4HANA, the transaction is BP (Business Partner). It consolidates customer, vendor, and contact data into a single master record. You assign roles like Customer (FLCU00/FLCU01) or Supplier (FLVN00/FLVN01) to the business partner depending on the business context. SAP introduced Customer/Vendor Integration (CVI) to unify master data. This simplifies data maintenance and supports innovations like multiple addresses, contact relationships, and streamlined integration with other modules.

For more information, go through this Blog

entry.content:

A few years ago - I had built a proof of concept of a similar functional setup for Ethereum and used the Chainlink Price Feed smart contracts for maintaining the exchange rate.

entry.title: Re: In S/4HANA what transaction will replace VC/2
entry.content: Will this show the full transaction history too, like the current VC/2

entry.title: Re: Update MWSKZ (TAX CODE) in ME21N
entry.content:
Use PROCESS_HEADER to Detect Partner Changes. In PROCESS_HEADER, use GET_PARTNER to retrieve the current partner list. Check for presence of 'ZF' or 'FO' partner functions. Store the relevant tax code in a global variable or memory object. Update EKPO-MWSKZ in PROCESS_ITEM using stored Tax Code. Please note, you’ll need to ensure PROCESS_ITEM is triggered after partner changes and hence, this may require a dummy field change or refresh logic to force reprocessing.
If the refresh logic is not working, consider POST method. This ensures the tax code is updated just before saving, based on the final partner list.

entry.title: Re: Issue with Missing Records in CDS Table Function (ABA...

entry.title: Re: In S/4HANA what transaction will replace VC/2
entry.content:
There is no standard report to my knowledge. You need to develop a custom report by considering several tables like

  • BUT000 – General BP master data
  • BUT020 – BP addresses
  • BUT100 – BP roles
  • BUT050 – BP relationships
  • BUT0ID – Identification numbers

or build CDS views to extract historical data

entry.title: MM_PUR_S4_PO_MODIFY_HEADER not triggered during Automatic Creation of PO from PR.

Currently I_PURCHASEORDEREMAILPARAMETER is not extensible so MM_PUR_S4_PO_MODIFY_HEADER is used to update custom fields in PO email template. This is working fine during creation/update of PO however MM_PUR_S4_PO_MODIFY_HEADER is not triggered during Automatic Creation of PO from PR.

How can you update custom fields for PO email template during automatic PO creation from PR? 

PUR_S4_PO_MODIFY_ITEM and MM_PUR_S4_PO_MODIFY_ITEM were checked however custom field cannot be used for email template.

entry.title: Re: How to take print output of delivery group in public...
entry.content:
Open the “Output Parameter Determination” app. Select the relevant object type; this may be listed as Delivery Group or similar (if available in 2502). Define Output Type Rules by creating a rule for the delivery group document type. Assign an output type (e.g., DELIVERY_GROUP_NOTE or a custom one). Set Dispatch Time to 1 – Immediately or 2 – Scheduled, depending on your process.

In the Channel step, choose EMAIL, PRINT, or EDI as needed. In the Receiver step, define who should receive the output (e.g., customer, internal user). Use the “Maintain Form Templates” app to assign a PDF form to your output type. If no standard form exists for delivery groups, you may need to create a custom Adobe form using Key User Extensibility.

entry.title: Re: Update MWSKZ (TAX CODE) in ME21N
entry.content: Thank you for your response, but when modifying or adding a partner role, the process header method is not called.

entry.title: Getting Started with SAP Fiori Development in Visual Studio Code (Open Source)
entry.content:
Getting Started with SAP Fiori Development in Visual Studio Code (Open Source)
To begin developing SAP Fiori applications using VS Code, follow these steps:

  1. Install Visual Studio Code on your system.

  2. Ensure Node.js and Git are installed as prerequisites.

  3. Set up the SAP Fiori tools extension pack from the VS Code Marketplace.

4. Once the extension is ready, click on View and select Command Palette...

5. Then, in the search bar, type 'Open Application Generator'.

6. For simple application click on Basic and click on Next

7. if you don't have any Data source select None and click Next

8. Enter the view name, this will serve as your page name.

9. Fill in the details such as the Module Name (Project Name). Enable or disable options based on your use case, then click Finish.

10. After clicking Finish, the setup will take a few moments to install the necessary Node modules.

11. Once the setup is complete, the following folder structure will be generated:
You will see a folder with your project name, containing a webapp directory. Inside webapp, you’ll find the view and controller folders:

  • The view folder contains XML files where you'll write the front-end UI code.

  • The controller folder contains JavaScript files where you'll implement logic and operations for the corresponding views.

Now, open view/View1.view.xml to begin editing your first page.

12. Add the custom code from Demo kit Get Started: Setup, Tutorials, and Demo Apps - Documentation - Demo Kit - SAPUI5 SDK

13. After adding your custom code, open the terminal and execute npm run start to launch the application locally.

14. Your application will now be up and running, it's that simple!

Please feel free to reach out to me if you encounter any difficulties while launching the application.

entry.title: Re: Custom PR Workflow type Overall release
entry.content: Yes, this is a known limitation in the Manage Workflows for Purchase Requisitions app. You can try with BAdI SWF_WORKFLOW_CONDITION_DEF which will let you to define custom preconditions (fields and value help) for workflow scenarios. You can expose custom fields—even those at item level—for use in overall release logic.

entry.title: Re: Enhancing SAP Digital Manufacturing with Extended iDoc: Addressing the Absence of Operation Long
entry.content:
@tandras_sap 

The General information field customized in the way explained in this post (enhanching the idoc and mapping it on the pp:LongText field) works and shows the information in the Operation/Phase list plugin of the Order POD

@SaraMani is there any updates on equivalent ways to display this information (the LongText mapped in the General Information field) in Work Center POD?
Furthermore, is there any equivalent way to map the same information about the LongText to the General Information field of the operations in the Master Routing that is downloaded via the LOIROU enhanced IDoc?

I tried mapping the information coming from the enhanced IDoc to a tag named <LongText> or also <longText> or even <GeneralInformation>, but it didn't work. The tag is present and correctly populated in the Request Payload of the Master Routing Download integration message, but it does not indeed get mapped on the General Information field of the operations in the Master Production Routing, differently from the Order Specific Routing where it gets correctly mapped after downloading a Production Order.

entry.title: Re: AS2 Credentials Strategy for Migrating PO Interfaces...
entry.content:
Client certificate authentication considerations:
1.Requires certificate exchange and trust setup (If trading partners support it)
2.Slightly higher initial setup effort (keystore management)

S-User + Basic Authentication Advantages: It is easier to implement initially, & Uses standard SAP authentication (with roles)
Limitations:
1.Password expiry policies (every 90 days, unless adjusted) and Manual rotation needed
2.Less secure than certificates for long-term automation

entry.title: Trading Partner within MM Subcontracting Consumption posting
entry.content:
Hello,

we face an issue in MM Subcontracting with an intercompany vendor. We use MM Subcontracting for a type of repair service. We send the broken item with a delivery related to a subcontracting purchase order, the item in the order is the same material number. When we receive the item back, the GR Posting also posts the consumption of the item sent (special stock in sending company) with trading partner. But this item is never owned by the IC vendor. Because of the system behaviour we get in trouble with our consolidation team, since this entry can not be consolidated with the IC vendor, so its a one side trading partner entry.

The propsal of SAP support is an implicit enhancement which we would like to avoid.

Has anybody a standard solution for this topic or maybe a process which does not cause such an issue?

Many thanks in advance!

Regards, Marion

entry.title: Assertion failed: 200130 (17.0.8.4046) Invalid page found in index - SQL Anywhere
entry.content:

We run database validation after such a crash, and validation was successful.
Dear experts, please share your opinions on this crash.
More context:
1) Linux Server
2) Virtual Machine
3) insert around 13Mln of records
SAP SQL Anywhere

entry.title: Re: How we can capture the number of shares/options (stoc...
entry.content:
Hi @Harshihash_0306,

In "Configure Object Definition", create a new object based on the "externalCode" at Subject User Field, so it can be added in the employee profile. 

In the object, define the required fields and what data type is required. 

Create it as a "Secured" object, so you can able to enable required permission for the relevant roles.

Refer the below KBA, MDF Objects in SAP SuccessFactors - SAP Community

Thanks & Regards

Arun

entry.content:
My Customer is using Panaya for Test execution. They have also SAP Cloud ALM installed but do not want to use currently Test Managment in the implementation part. But they have a Setup of a Project in SAP Cloud ALM ( RISE) .

Now they would like to have an interface between Panaya and SAP Clou ALM to exchange the Testdefecs which are coming from Panaya into SAP Cloud ALM. Since we have no SAP Cloud ALM using for manual Test execution, I think about to Exchange the Test Defects in SAP Cloud ALM as a Task or a Feature,. Feature would have the advantage to connect Transports to it in case, they need to deploy some system changes. 

Any experiences or recommendation very welcome 

 

BR Danie

entry.title: Re: GR/IR issue
entry.content:
Possible causes of GR/IR Imbalance with WBS Elements could be due to the following:-

  • If the PO is in a foreign currency and Concur applies a different exchange rate, small rounding differences can cause mismatches.
  • Concur may not always pass back exact PO line item references, especially for split or partial invoices. If the invoice doesn’t match the GR quantity or value, SAP won’t clear the GR/IR account automatically.
  • If the WBS element isn’t consistently assigned across the PO, GR, and IR, SAP can’t reconcile the amounts properly. This can happen if Concur sends back accounting data without the correct WBS linkage.
  • If the GR is posted after the invoice, or vice versa, the system may temporarily show an imbalance. This is more likely in asynchronous integrations like Concur → SAP.

entry.title: Re: How to prevent deletion of specific entry in Event 03...
entry.content:
Same answer as @hangaos but with solution more oriented to solution by SAP Library (alas, by using old ABAP, e.g. obsolete header line and subroutine, but SM30 is old anyway).

<xmark> is a standard field symbol pointing to the field MARK of EXTRACT, and MARKIERT is constant 'M' for field MARK (marked/selected row).

FORM on_delete.
  FIELD-SYMBOLS <ls_zsap03_email> TYPE zsap03_email.

  ASSIGN extract TO <your_table_or_view> CASTING.

  LOOP AT extract.
    IF     <xmark>                   = markiert
       AND <ls_zsap03_email>-user_id = 'DEV-145'.
      MESSAGE 'Default row DEV-145 cannot be deleted!' TYPE 'E'.
    ENDIF.
  ENDLOOP.
ENDFORM.

entry.title: Re: Creation of custom CDS view in S/4 Public Cloud
entry.content:
Since CDS views do not support DISTINCT directly, we ensure uniqueness by:

  • Using associations instead of joins.
  • Selecting only key fields from the base view.
  • Avoiding 1:N relationships unless aggregated or filtered.
  • Optionally using GROUP BY if needed.
    •  


    Sample CDS View

    @AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZV_SALES_DEL_RET'
    @AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
    @EndUserText.label: 'Sales Order with Delivery and Return Info'
    define view ZC_SalesDeliveryReturn
    as select from I_SalesOrderItemCube as Sales
    {
    key Sales.SalesDocument,
    key Sales.SalesDocumentItem,
    Sales.Material,
    Sales.NetAmount,
    Sales.TransactionCurrency,

    // Currency conversion (optional)
    cast_amount(
    Sales.NetAmount,
    Sales.TransactionCurrency,
    'USD',
    Sales.CreationDate,
    'M',
    'SAP',
    'EURX'
    ) as NetAmountInUSD,

    // Association fields
    _DeliveryItem.DeliveryDocument,
    _DeliveryItem.DeliveryDocumentItem,
    _CustomerReturnItem.CustomerReturnDocument,
    _CustomerReturnItem.ReturnQuantity
    }

    // Association to Delivery Document Item
    association [0..1] to I_DeliveryDocumentItem as _DeliveryItem
    on Sales.SalesDocument = _DeliveryItem.ReferenceSDDocument
    and Sales.SalesDocumentItem = _DeliveryItem.ReferenceSDDocumentItem

    // Association to Customer Return Item
    association [0..1] to I_CustomerReturnItemCube_2 as _CustomerReturnItem
    on Sales.SalesDocument = _CustomerReturnItem.OriginalSalesDocument
    and Sales.SalesDocumentItem = _CustomerReturnItem.OriginalSalesDocumentItem

    [0..1] cardinality ensures only one matching record is expected per association.

    If there are multiple delivery or return items per sales item, consider:
    • Creating intermediate views that aggregate them (e.g., MAX(ReturnQuantity)).
    • Using GROUP BY in a wrapper view to consolidate.

      Currency Conversion in CDS

      SAP provides a standard currency conversion function in CDS views using the annotation:
      @Semantics.amount.currencyCode: 'CurrencyField'


      cast_amount( Sales.NetAmount,
                   Sales.Currency,
                   'USD',
                   Sales.CurrencyConversionDate,
                   'M',
                   'SAP',
                   'EURX' ) as NetAmountInUSD

When checking app Customer Data Browser, we want to display all finance data (ACDOCA) in cds views. According to hub https://api.sap.com/cdsviews/I_JOURNALENTRYITEM, the cds view should be I_JournalEntryItem (Basic).

This is not what we want. We want to directly check the journal entry line item data in public cloud, just like we can check the data of the header system.

 

Besides, we also found the cds view: I_ACCOUNTINGDOCUMENTJOURNAL. But we see that the amount of fields are not the same. Not sure if we can use this one though.

entry.title: Re: Trading Partner within MM Subcontracting Consumption...
entry.content:
In subcontracting, SAP automatically posts a goods issue (543 movement type) for the component (in your case, the broken item) when the GR for the finished product is posted. If the same material number is used for both the component and the finished product, SAP treats the component as consumed and posts the trading partner from the vendor master. However, in intercompany scenarios, the vendor is part of your corporate group, and the item was never truly transferred in ownership—it was just sent for repair. This leads to a one-sided trading partner entry, which causes issues in consolidation, since the IC vendor never posted a corresponding entry.

Recommended approaches would be

  • use a Different Material Number for the Repaired Item. Create a distinct material number for the repaired version (e.g., with a suffix like _REPAIRED). This avoids automatic consumption logic and trading partner assignment during GR. You can still link the two materials via material relationships or BOMs if needed.
  • Configure the component as non-valuated in the receiving company. This prevents the system from posting a financial entry during consumption. You may need to adjust valuation class and account determination settings.

Additionally, consider using subcontracting with service PO instead of material PO if the repair doesn’t involve material transformation.

If you're still in design or pilot phase, go with Approach 1 for simplicity and audit clarity. If you're deep into implementation and can't change material numbers,  then, consider approach 2 for backend control.

entry.title: Re: SPED in S4HANA Private Cloud - NACE or Output Management
entry.content:
The answer is NO, not yet. As of release 02/2024, SPED (output type for triggering inbound delivery from STO outbound delivery) is still tied to the legacy NAST framework, and not supported in the new Output Management (BRF+).

SPED is a system-triggered output that initiates a follow-on document (inbound delivery). The new Output Management in S/4HANA (based on BRF+) focuses on external outputs like print, email, and EDI—not system integration triggers like SPED. SAP has not yet migrated SPED into the Output Control reuse service, and there’s no standard output type in BRF+ that replicates SPED’s behavior.

What you can do is you can activate NACE selectively for specific output types like SPED. This hybrid approach is supported in S/4HANA Private Cloud, where both frameworks can coexist. If you want to avoid NACE entirely, consider implementing a custom BAdI or output determination logic that triggers inbound delivery creation based on outbound delivery events. This would mimic SPED behavior but requires development effort.

Finally, Keep an eye on blogs like this  and SAP notes like 3097507

entry.title: Manage Business Partner (F3163) – Only one payment method allowed
entry.content:
We are using the “Manage Business Partner” app (F3163) in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and have found that, both in migration and in direct creation of Business Partners, it is not possible to add more than one payment method. 

However, using the classic “Maintain Business Partner” app (transaction BP), it is possible to enter multiple payment methods as expected.

This limitation in F3163 has an impact on our master data management and maintenance processes and is not documented as a functional or technical limitation.

 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Manage Business Partner (F3163) – Only one payment me...
entry.content:
The Fiori apps, including "Manage Business Partner Master Data App," "Manage Customer Master Data App," and "Manage Supplier Master Data App," are designed as lighter versions for specific use cases. These apps include only the most commonly used fields and do not support maintaining multiple payment methods.
Use the "Maintain Business Partner" app to maintain multiple payment methods.
  1. Open the "Maintain Business Partner" app.
  2. Open the relevant Business Partner (BP).
  3. Display the BP in the role of Supplier (Financial Accounting) or Customer (Financial Accounting).
  4. Navigate to the "Company Code" tab.
  5. Navigate to the "Supplier: Payment Transactions" tab.
  6. Under the "Automatic Payment Transaction" section, maintain multiple payment methods.

Refer this KBA for more details : Maintaining multiple Payment Methods is not possible in the Fiori apps

entry.title: We have successfully activated End user Logon functionality in SAP GRC. Clarification on below queri
entry.content:
Our understanding of the End User Logon feature is that it should allow users who do not have direct access to the SAP GRC system to access the End User Logon screen—for example, to raise access requests or perform self-service tasks.

However, in our current setup, only users who already have some level of access to SAP GRC are able to log in via the End User Logon screen. Users without any existing GRC access are unable to authenticate through this interface.

Request for Clarification:
Is it expected behavior that the End User Logon screen only allows users with existing GRC access to log in?

If not, could you please advise if we might have missed any configuration steps while enabling the End User Logon functionality?

Kindly guide us on how to enable logon for users who do not already have access to the core GRC system but need to use the End User Logon interface.

entry.title: SAP Joule for Custom Fiori App blueprint development
entry.content:
Today I decided to challenge SAP Joule by rebuilding a custom UI5 application that I originally developed 5–6 years ago in SAP Web IDE. I wanted to explore how far Joule has come, how well it handles complex UI logic, and whether it truly helps developers accelerate Fiori app development.

 

 

Hi! I'm Joule, your digital assistant.

How can I help you?

In your prompt, enter:

/ at the beginning for commands

# to reference a file from your context

Though I strive for perfection, I might not get everything right all the time.

You

/ui5 Add a Table

You

/ui5 /add 7 columns including invoice number, description, date, currency , amount, vendor id, conversion rate

You

/code-search replace SalespredicationApp this with salespredicationapp

You

/ui5 column should be input type

You

/help

You

/ui5 Error: adding element with duplicate id 'application-app-preview-component---App'

You

/ui5 date column should have date control date picker, amount column should allow only amount

You

/ui5 check routing as it is giving duplicate id error Error: adding element with duplicate id 'application-app-preview-component---App

 You

/ui5 Error: Control with ID app could not be found - Target: TargetApp

You

/ui5 table should be sap.ui.table.Table add features like add rows and add multiple rows, edit rows, upload the data and download the data , stick column headers, mass update of date add these features in tool bar also add delete row feature

 You

/ui5 implement the functions or method in controller make it work able

You

/ui5 add 15 rows of dummy data and display only 10rows rest should be next like paging

 You

/ui5 Before showing the whole app make a pop up appear and ask user to select the continent give all 7 continents options whatever user select based on that display countries of that continents

I approached it not just as a developer, but more like a user giving functional instructions — and to my surprise, Joule managed to complete most of the tasks in just 2–4 hours.

 

 

 

 

  1. It shows the total of the rows
  2. Addonly one row
  3. Add multiple rows
  4. Edit row make it editable
  5. Delete the selected row
  6. Upload the excel file display into table
  7. Downlaod the data into excel sheet
  8. Mass update the selected rows date it will give pop up user allowed to select the date and click ok yeah date updated for selected rows

 

These points I gather while developing scratch solution may be it will be different or pricing model and fiori elements.

 

 

 

SAP Joule – Developer Pain Points & Limitations

  1.   No Clear Code Change Highlighting
  2.   Replacing Existing Code Instead of Inserting
  3.   Refresh = Lost Context

“When I refresh, I lose the previous instructions I gave.”

  • Joule does not persist conversation state between browser refreshes or sessions.
  • This breaks continuity for complex, multi-step app development.
  • No "history" or "thread memory" means you have to re-explain your app every time

 

  1. File Creation Can Be Inconsistent

“If you give specific instructions, it creates separate files — but if not, it sometimes fails to create the file in the project.”

  • Joule’s file management logic is not always reliable:
    • It might try to add a new controller/view but fail silently
    • Sometimes appends to wrong files if structure is unclear
    • You need to manually double-check whether the file was generated or not

 

 Suggested Improvements (If Reporting to SAP)

Visual change tracking (like Git diff or highlights)

  •  Insert vs replace awareness (component-level granularity)
  •  Session memory or project instruction history
  •  Robust file creation & feedback system
  •  Optional "simulation mode" to preview changes before applying

SAP Joule – Pros (Developer Experience)

 

 

  • Massive Time Savings
  • Focus on Business Logic, Not Boilerplate
  • Productivity Boost
  • Helpful for Modernizing Legacy Apps

 

      • Migrating apps from SAP Web IDE to BAS or UI5 with latest standards becomes much easier.
      • Joule suggests modern coding practices like const/let, MVC separation, and dynamic binding.

 

  • Learning Support
  • Rapid Prototyping - Great for quick POCs, MVPs, or demo apps where speed is critical.
  • Developer-Friendly Experience

SAP Joule – Cons (Developer Perspective)

  1. Reduced Logical Thinking
  2. Restricted Skill Growth
  3. Lack of Understanding
    • When code is auto-generated, developers might not fully understand:
      • Why certain logic is used
      • How bindings work
      • Lifecycle hooks in UI5 or Fiori
  4. Less Practice in Debugging
  5. Over-Reliance on Templates
  6. Weakening of Core Programming Skills
  7. Barrier to Innovation
    • When developers follow AI-generated patterns, they may hesitate to experiment with alternative or more optimal solutions.

 

 

 

Use Joule for...

Avoid Joule for...

Generating repetitive boilerplate

Solving business-critical logic

Kickstarting a CRUD app

Deep customization or performance tuning

Learning syntax or APIs quickly

Building your foundational knowledge

entry.title: SAP MDG: How to restrict not req. document type in SAP MDG Change Request (Customer/Supplier) UI?
entry.content:
Hi SCN Folks, 

Note: I didn't add Change Request UI Screenshots.

Faced the Problem:
Configured some Z Document Types. While choosing document types while creating of Change request (It usually displays Custom + Standard Document Types) but i don't want to display standard document types. 

How to solve the problem:
please find below process to clear the faced problem 🙂

Go to the below navigation:
SPRO > Cross-Application Components > Document Management > Control Data > Define DMS Document Types.

Choose the document type & go to the navigation—Define Object Links. Choose the LFA1 & delete it.

As it should not show for the supplier change request.

SAP Master Data Governance 

Thank You, 
Sandeep Suggu.
SAP Community | LinkedIn

entry.title: How to Cascade Production Cuts from a Semi-Finished Product to Finished Products in SAP IBP S&OP
entry.content:
How to Cascade Production Cuts from a Semi-Finished Product to Finished Products in SAP IBP S&OP (without Supply & Response)
I’m working with the SAP IBP S&OP module (only the S&OP Optimizer and/or Heuristics are enabled — Supply & Response is not activated).

In our scenario, we have a production constraint for a semi-finished product. The challenge is: we would like to manually reduce the production plan of this semi-finished product, and have this reduction automatically cascade to the finished products that depend on it (through the product BOM structure).

Is there a way — using only S&OP functionalities — to ensure that when the plan for a semi-finished product is adjusted down, the demand and/or production plan for the dependent finished products is reduced accordingly?

More context:
• The production capacity is constrained at the semi-finished level.
• We are not using Supply Planning or Response features.
• The finished products share the semi-finished component and must reflect its limitation.

Are there any best practices, configuration tips, or workaround approaches (e.g., specific BOM settings, planning operators, key figures interactions, disaggregation/reaggregation logic) that can help implement this logic within S&OP?

Thank you in advance for your support!

entry.title: How to Handle Multi-Country Assignments with Aggregated Bonus Payout and Individual Ratings in VP
entry.content:
Hi experts,

I’m working with a client who has a complex scenario in SAP SuccessFactors Variable Pay. The bonus program runs from 01 Jan 2025 to 31 Dec 2025, and some employees may have multiple international assignments within the same program year. For example:

  • Sweden: 01 Jan 2025 – 30 Apr 2025
  • Spain: 01 May 2025 – 31 Aug 2025
  • China: 01 Sep 2025 – 31 Dec 2025

Due to EC standard behavior, each international move creates a new employment (rehire) with a new User ID, which breaks the continuity of bonus eligibility and assignment history.

To work around this, we’re using a Hybrid Variable Pay template where:

  • The employee is processed under the final assignment (e.g., China).
  • The previous assignments (Sweden and Spain) are manually added to the Employee History File with correct bonus plan, target amount, and business goal results using non-EC rules.

This setup works well for payout aggregation, but we’re facing a challenge with Individual Performance Ratings:

  • Ratings are not reflected in (ABR) unless the Assignment Match Rule with PM Forms aligns perfectly.
  • In cases where assignment dates (e.g., 10 Mar – 10 Aug) don’t match the PM form dates, the rating is ignored.
  • Using “Import by Assignment History” as the rating source doesn’t help either, since it’s manual and doesn’t support guidelines or custom validations in VP forms.

Question:
Is there any recommended workaround or best practice to handle individual performance ratings in such multi-country assignment scenarios — especially when using a hybrid template and aggregated payout logic?

Thanks in advance!
Best Regard,

entry.title: How do you handle multiple origin (xsuaa.origin) when provisioning to a BTP Subaccount?
entry.content:
Hello Community,

Challenge

  • In SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), managing users with both platform roles (for administrative tasks like managing subaccounts) and business roles (for application specific access) requires careful configuration to ensure the correct identity provider IdP is assigned based on the role type when you want to use your own Identity provider (SAP Cloud Identity Services) and not the default IdP of SAP....

Context

  • The xsuaaa.origin attribute in SAP IPS provisioning systems determines with which IdP a user is created in the BTP accounts. The challenge is to configure SAP Cloud Identity Services – Identity Provisioning to handle this distinction during user and authorization provisioning.
    • Platform Roles: The roles grant access to platform-level resources, such as the SAP BTP cockpit for managing subaccounts, services and subscriptions. Users with platform roles authenticate via a platform IdP, such as the Default IdP or a custom platform IdP. ("<tenant>-platform" 
    • Business Roles: These roles grant access to specific applications deployed in a subaccount. Users with business roles authenticate via an application IdP (" sap.custom" origin)  .

Options

1.Always provision multiple origins, so user will be created with both Platform as Application IdP

–Solution direction is prepared by SAP (Configure Single and Multiple Origins | SAP Help Portal)

2.Develop more refined logic to create users with the appropriate IdP assignment on the BTP platform based on role / group type assignment?

I noticed other user have touched this topic since there two improvement requests in this area:

  1. Improvement Request Details - Customer Influence
  2. Improvement Request Details - Customer Influence

It would be much appreciated if the community is willing to share there approach to this specific topic regarding handling the origin attribute in the subaccount.

 

 

The setup above always creates a user with both the sap.custom as the platform origin IdP (and assign the role collections also to both entries). This works, but is not a very refined approach....
